natural problem: A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen?
natural solution: Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.

Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.

In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a + b > c"
and h4 : "a + c > b"
and h5 : "b + c > a"
and h6 : "\<forall> x. x > 0 \<and> x \<le> a \<and> x \<le> b \<and> x \<le> c \<longrightarrow> (a - x) + (b - x) \<le> (c - x)"
shows  "x = 6"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a + b > c"
and h4 : "a + c > b"
and h5 : "b + c > a"
and h6 : "\<forall> x. x > 0 \<and> x \<le> a \<and> x \<le> b \<and> x \<le> c \<longrightarrow> (a - x) + (b - x) \<le> (c - x)"
shows  "x = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given that $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, find a value of $x$ that is greater than 0 and less than or equal to $a$, $b$, and $c$ such that $(a - x) + (b - x) \leq (c - x)$. The final answer is $x = 6$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c x :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - x > 0"
and h4 : "b - x > 0"
and h5 : "c - x > 0"
and h6 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (b - x) > (c - x) \<and> (a - x) + (c - x) > (b - x) \<and> (b - x) + (c - x) > (a - x))"
shows  "x = 6"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c x :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - x > 0"
and h4 : "b - x > 0"
and h5 : "c - x > 0"
and h6 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (b - x) > (c - x) \<and> (a - x) + (c - x) > (b - x) \<and> (b - x) + (c - x) > (a - x))"
shows  "x = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the values $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, find the value of $x$ such that $a - x > 0$, $b - x > 0$, $c - x > 0$, and the triangle inequality is not satisfied for the new lengths $(a - x)$, $(b - x)$, and $(c - x)$. The final answer is $x = 6$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem triangle_inequality:
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a + b > c"
and h1 : "a + c > b"
and h2 : "b + c > a"
and h3 : "a - x > 0"
and h4 : "b - x > 0"
and h5 : "c - x > 0"
and h6 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (b - x) > c)"
and h7 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (c - x) > b)"
and h8 : "\<not> ((b - x) + (c - x) > a)"
and h9 : "a = 8"
and h10 : "b = 15"
and h11 : "c = 17"
shows  "x = 6"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem triangle_inequality:
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a + b > c"
and h1 : "a + c > b"
and h2 : "b + c > a"
and h3 : "a - x > 0"
and h4 : "b - x > 0"
and h5 : "c - x > 0"
and h6 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (b - x) > c)"
and h7 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (c - x) > b)"
and h8 : "\<not> ((b - x) + (c - x) > a)"
and h9 : "a = 8"
and h10 : "b = 15"
and h11 : "c = 17"
shows  "x = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Given a triangle with side lengths $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, find a positive value $x$ such that after subtracting $x$ from each side length, the triangle inequality does not hold for the resulting triangle. The final answer is $x = 6$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c x :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - x > 0 \<and> b - x > 0 \<and> c - x > 0"
and h4 : "\<not> (a - x < b - x + c - x \<and> b - x < a - x + c - x \<and> c - x < a - x + b - x)"
shows  "x = 6"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof

 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c x :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - x > 0 \<and> b - x > 0 \<and> c - x > 0"
and h4 : "\<not> (a - x < b - x + c - x \<and> b - x < a - x + c - x \<and> c - x < a - x + b - x)"
shows  "x = 6"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Suppose there are three lengths, $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$. Find a value for $x$ such that after subtracting $x$ from each of the lengths, at least one of the triangle inequality conditions is violated. The final answer is $x = 6$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - d < b - d"
and h4 : "a - d < c - d"
and h5 : "b - d < c - d"
and h6 : "a - d + b - d > c - d"
and h7 : "a - d + c - d > b - d"
and h8 : "b - d + c - d > a - d"
and h9 : "d > 0"
shows  "d = 6"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - d < b - d"
and h4 : "a - d < c - d"
and h5 : "b - d < c - d"
and h6 : "a - d + b - d > c - d"
and h7 : "a - d + c - d > b - d"
and h8 : "b - d + c - d > a - d"
and h9 : "d > 0"
shows  "d = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: There are four natural numbers a, b, c, and d. a is 8, b is 15, and c is 17. It is given that a - d < b - d, a - d < c - d, b - d < c - d, a - d + b - d > c - d, a - d + c - d > b - d, b - d + c - d > a - d, and d > 0. Find the value of d. The final answer is 6.

(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6

 *)

theorem
fixes a b c x :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "\<not> ((a - x) + (b - x) > (c - x) \<and> (a - x) + (c - x) > (b - x) \<and> (b - x) + (c - x) > (a - x))"
shows  "x = 6"

a_5.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ such that $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, but none of the following inequalities hold true: $(a - x) + (b - x) > (c - x)$, $(a - x) + (c - x) > (b - x)$, and $(b - x) + (c - x) > (a - x)$. The final answer is $x = 6$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c x :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "\<forall> a b c. a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a \<longrightarrow> (a - x) + (b - x) > (c - x) \<and> (a - x) + (c - x) > (b - x) \<and> (b - x) + (c - x) > (a - x)"
shows  "x = 6"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c x :: nat
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "\<forall> a b c. a + b > c \<and> a + c > b \<and> b + c > a \<longrightarrow> (a - x) + (b - x) > (c - x) \<and> (a - x) + (c - x) > (b - x) \<and> (b - x) + (c - x) > (a - x)"
shows  "x = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given the triangle with side lengths $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, find a value for $x$ such that if you subtract $x$ from each side length, the resulting triangle is still valid. The final answer is $x = 6$.

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int

(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6

 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a - d > 0"
and h4 : "b - d > 0"
and h5 : "c - d > 0"
and h6 : "\<not>((a - d) + (b - d) > (c - d) \<and> (a - d) + (c - d) > (b - d) \<and> (b - d) + (c - d) > (a - d))"
shows  "d = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Given the integers $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, find an integer $d$ such that $a - d > 0$, $b - d > 0$, and $c - d > 0$, but the sum of any two of these differences is not greater than the third. The final answer is $d = 6$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "\<forall> d. d > 0 \<longrightarrow> (a - d) + (b - d) < (c - d)"
shows  "d = 6"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c d :: int
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "\<forall> d. d > 0 \<longrightarrow> (a - d) + (b - d) < (c - d)"
shows  "d = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Suppose we have the integers a, b, and c with a equals to 8, b equals to 15, and c equals to 17. Find an integer d greater than 0, such that when subtracted from a, b, and c respectively, the sum of the resulting values for a and b is still less than the resulting value for c. The final answer is d equals to 6.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a + b > c"
and h4 : "a + c > b"
and h5 : "b + c > a"
and h6 : "\<forall> d. d \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (a - d) + (b - d) > (c - d)"
shows  "\<exists> d. d > 0 \<and> (a - d) + (b - d) \<le> (c - d) \<and> d = 6"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 A triangle is made of wood sticks of lengths 8, 15 and 17 inches joined end-to-end. Pieces of the same integral length are cut from each of the sticks so that the three remaining pieces can no longer form a triangle. How many inches are in the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks to make this happen? The final Answer is 6
 ### Proof
 Our current triangle lengths are 8, 15, and 17.
 Let us say that $x$ is the length of the piece that we cut from each of the three sticks. Then, our lengths will be $8 - x,$ $15 - x,$ and $17 - x.$ These lengths will no longer form a triangle when the two shorter lengths added together is shorter than or equal to the longest length.
 In other words, $(8 - x) + (15 - x) \leq (17 - x).$ Then, we have $23 - 2x \leq 17 - x,$ so $6 \leq x.$ Therefore, the length of the smallest piece that can be cut from each of the three sticks is $\boxed{6}$ inches.
 *)

theorem
fixes a b c :: real
assumes h0 : "a = 8"
and h1 : "b = 15"
and h2 : "c = 17"
and h3 : "a + b > c"
and h4 : "a + c > b"
and h5 : "b + c > a"
and h6 : "\<forall> d. d \<ge> 0 \<longrightarrow> (a - d) + (b - d) > (c - d)"
shows  "\<exists> d. d > 0 \<and> (a - d) + (b - d) \<le> (c - d) \<and> d = 6"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given that $a = 8$, $b = 15$, and $c = 17$, and knowing that the sum of any two of these numbers is greater than the third one, find a positive number $d$ such that when subtracted from $a$, $b$, and $c$, the sum of the reduced $a$ and $b$ is less than or equal to the reduced $c$. The final answer is $d = 6$.
